summary: James Garrison is mentioned in the context of the JFK assassination investigation. The documents suggest that his investigation was a matter of interest to the CIA, as evidenced by references to the "Garrison investigation" in relation to Gordon Novel's claims of CIA affiliation. He is also mentioned in the context of the JFK Assassination Records Collection Act of 1992, indicating that records related to his investigation were subject to review and release. The documents do not provide a detailed timeline of his involvement but highlight the CIA's awareness and monitoring of individuals connected to his investigation.
key_connections: JFK Assassination Records Collection Act of 1992
significance: James Garrison's significance lies in his role as the New Orleans District Attorney who conducted an investigation into the JFK assassination, which led to the prosecution of Clay Shaw. His investigation and its connections to individuals claiming CIA ties were of interest to the CIA, as reflected in the documents.
